New Records: Denmark have drawn all three of their group games for the first time ever at a major tournament (World Cup & Euros).
Serbia's total haul of six shots on target at Euro 2024 is their lowest-ever figure as an independent nation at a major tournament (World Cup & Euros since 2006).
Christian Eriksen created the most chances ever by a Danish player at a major tournament on record (World Cup & Euros since 1980) with a total of 13 at Euro 2024.
Key Match Events: Alexander Bah headed a good chance off target after 15 minutes and 40 seconds, the longest wait for the first shot in a Euro 2024 match so far.
Dusan Tadic sliced open the Denmark defence to feed Luka Jovic, but he strayed offside before seeing his wayward shot knocked into the net by Joachim Andersen.

Aleksandar Mitrovic contested 13 aerial duels in the first half, more than any other player across an entire game in this tournament, and ended the game with 23 aerials, the second most by anyone in a single Euros game as far back as 1980.
Sergej Milinkovic-Savic's late effort from the edge of the box was as close as Serbia came to scoring, but it was a tame shot.
Pre-Game Insights: Denmark coach Kasper Hjulmand said pre-game, 'We always want to win, we miss being in the locker room singing about how we won, that’s what we want.'
Post-Match Reflections: Denmark coach Kasper Hjulmand reflected on the draw, stating that although they miss winning, they are happy to progress to the next stage.
Denmark have qualified for the knockout stages of a UEFA European Championship on three of their last four attempts (reaching the quarter-finals in 2004 and the semi-finals in 2020).

Serbia are now without a victory in their last eight major tournament matches (Euros/World Cup – D3 L5), since a 1-0 win over Costa Rica at the 2018 World Cup, their joint longest winless run at major tournaments (also a run of eight as Yugoslavia between 1974 and 1982).
Miscellaneous Highlights: Denmark ended the group stage with the third-lowest xG against (2.3) among the teams to have played three matches.
Denmark named their oldest starting XI for a UEFA European Championship game since 2004, courtesy of a 2-2 group stage draw with Sweden (29y 72d).
